Award.AbstractNarration:
Networks are ubiquitous in the modern world, with social networks and the World Wide Web as well-known examples. Understanding the structure of networks is critical to understanding real-world phenomena, making predictions, and helping inform decisions on, for example, strategies to disrupt and dismantle terrorist networks, curb the spread of infectious diseases, and reduce systematic risk in financial markets. To help understand and predict such phenomena in the face of uncertainty, professionals need statistical models which are both complex and scalable (i.e., models which are capable of modeling a wide range of network characteristics and which can be applied to large networks). Existing models are either scalable but simplistic or complex but not scalable. This research project will develop the first generation of models which are both complex and scalable. The developed models and methods will have applications in a wide range of areas, including national security (e.g., insurgencies, terrorism), public health (e.g., the spread of infectious diseases), and finance (e.g., systematic risk in financial markets).

This research project will develop the next generation of random graph models which are both complex and scalable by merging the two most important streams of statistical network analysis, stochastic block models and exponential-family random graph models, with a view to reducing the disadvantages of each while retaining the advantages of both. Stochastic block models are scalable but simplistic, whereas exponential-family random graph models are complex but not scalable. The next-generation models studied here bridge the gap between complexity and scalability and are both complex and scalable. In addition to elaborating next-generation models, this research will address the unique computational and theoretical challenges raised by next-generation models. The computational challenge of estimating next-generation models will be addressed by taking advantage of model structure, including local dependence and local convexity properties, and by exploiting massive-scale minorization-maximization methods which break down the high-dimensional optimization problem into low-dimensional ones that can solved in parallel. The theoretical challenge of studying the properties of estimators will be addressed by exploiting novel concentration of measure inequalities. The concentration of measure inequalities will take into account the dependence inherent in networks as well as the lack of smoothness of estimators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

NSF award DMS-1513644 supported the development of next-generation network models that combine the benefits of two popular classes of network models:
(a) models with community structure, which assume that population members belong to communities and the propensities of population members to form relationships depend on communities, but which assume that relationships do not depend on other relationships;
(b) models without community structure, but which allow relationships to depend on other relationships.
These two classes of models belong to the most popular classes of network models, but each of them has disadvantages: models with community structure make the unwarranted assumption that relationships do not depend on other relationships, whereas models without community structure do not capture who is close to whom. The goal of next-generation network models is to combine the advantages of both classes of models while reducing the disadvantages of each of them. The research funded by NSF award DMS-1513644 has demonstrated the practical and theoretical benefits of doing so.

One of the most important intellectual contributions made by NSF award DMS-1513644 is that the PI's team has managed to narrow the large gap between statistical practice and theory:

Since the 1950s, scientists have argued that relationships depend on other relationships: e.g., the phenomenon that "a friend of a friend is a friend" suggests that friendships are dependent. The development of models for dependent relationships started in the 1980s and has gained momentum since the turn of the twenty-first century. In practice, more often than not, such models are estimated based on a single observation of a population network. That raises an important question:

What can be learned about a connected world where relationships depend on other relationships, without having the benefit of independent observations from the same source? Which statistical guarantees can be obtained?

While statistical guarantees have been established for models which assume that relationships are independent (within and between communities), no statistical guarantees are known for models that allow relationships to depend on other relationships, which are of great interest to scientists. The lack of known statistical guarantees has created problems for scientists: e.g., some funding agencies have become wary of funding research involving models with dependent relationships, citing concerns about the lack of known statistical guarantees.

The PI's team has taken first steps to show that statistical inference for dependent relationships with statistical guarantees is possible, provided community structure is available. These results have been published in the Annals of Statistics, the premier journal on statistical theory.

Broader Impacts: Science

Many scientists (e.g., health and social scientists, economics, epidemiologists) have attempted to understand a connected world in which relationships depend on other relationships. But the lack of known statistical guarantees has created problems for scientists: e.g., some funding agencies have become wary of funding research involving models with dependent relationships, citing concerns about the lack of known statistical guarantees. The PI's team has taken first steps to address those concerns. In so doing, the PI's team has provided critical support for scientists who want to understand a connected world.

To help scientists take advantage of community structure while allowing relationships to be dependent, the PI's team has published R packages hergm and mlergm. In addition, the PI's team has documented these R packages in the Journal of Statistical Software, the premier journal on statistical software, and published a full-fledged application in Social Networks, the premier journal on social network analysis.

Broader Impacts: Society

The PI's team is using the R packages hergm and mlergm to study the spread of HIV in Houston, TX, which is a part of an NIH-funded study of HIV in Houston, TX, Chicago, IL, and Los Angeles, CA.

In addition, the NSF award has helped train the next generation of data scientists. Two graduate students have been trained at Rice University. One student graduated in 2017 and is working as a senior data scientist at Microsoft in the Seattle metropolitan region. The other student is expected to graduate in 2019. Two additional graduate students, one student based at Rice University and the other student based at the University of Texas in Houston, were involved in research.
